facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated September 12, 1956 of Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 15 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated September 12, 1956, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 15 of 1955.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on August 16, 1961 by SUBBA RAO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. August 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO, J.-This appeal raises the question

facts.text: First respondent Laxmi Narayan Chopra carries on business as motor coach builder under Chopra Motors at 139, Regent Park, Tollygunge, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent, Laxmi Narayan Chopra, carries on business, as motor companych builder, under the name and style of Chopra Motors having, his factory at 139, Regent Park, Tollygunge in the suburbs of Calcutta.,

facts.text: In the factory, number of Universal Electric Motors operated for working electric drills.

anchor.surface_text: In the said factory a number of Universal Electric Motors are operated for the purpose of working electric drills.

facts.text: Post and Telegraph Wireless Station within 100 feet of the factory.

anchor.surface_text: Within a distance of 100 feet of the said factory, there is a Post and Telegraph Wireless Station, which, besides functioning as a companyst station

facts.text: Wireless Station functions as coast station communicating with ships at sea and handles public messages from Darjeeling, Shillong, Gauhati, Agartala, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: companyst station companymunicating with ships at sea, handles public messages in large volume from Darjeeling, Shillong, Gauhati, Agartala and New Delhi.

facts.text: In or about April 1953, severe electrical interference observed in the station attributed to local induction from first respondent's factory.

anchor.surface_text: In or about Aril, 1953 severe electrical interference was observed in the said station and experts attributed the same. to local induction from the first respondents factory.

facts.text: On October 13, 1953, Senior Electric Inspector issued notice to first respondent to show cause why order under s.34(2)(b) requiring discontinuation of Universal Electric Motors.

anchor.surface_text: On October 13, 1953, the Senior Electric Inspector issued a numberice to the first respondent to show cause writing as to why an order under s. 34 2  b  of the Act, read with numberification No. 4193-COM, dated August 1 14, 1929 requiring discontinuation of the operation of the Universal Electric Motors

facts.text: On December 1, 1953, Senior Electric Inspector made order under s.34(2)(b) requiring first respondent to remedy injuries affecting lines for wireless telegraphic communications.

anchor.surface_text: After some companyrespondence on December 1, 1953, the Senior Electric Inspector made an order under a. 34 2  b  of the Act requiring the first respondent to remedy the injuries affecting the lines used for wireless telegraphic companymunications at- the Wireless Receiving Centre.

facts.text: On January 12, 1954, first respondent filed petition in Calcutta High Court under Art. 226 for writ of mandamus to withdraw and cancel the order.

anchor.surface_text: On January 12, 1954, the first respondent filed a petition in the High Court at Calcutta under Art. 226 of the Constitution pray for a writ of mandamus or any other appropriate mug writ directing the appellants to withdraw and cancel the said order

facts.text: Petition heard first by Sinha J. who rejected contention that no telegraph line and dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: The petition came up for hearing, in the first instance, before Sinha J., of that Court. It was companytended, interalia, that there was numbertelegraph line in the Post and Telegraph Wireless Station within the meaning of s.34 2  b  of the Act, and, therefore, the numberice issued by the Senior Electric Inspector was without jurisdiction. Sinha J., rejected the companytention and dismissed the petition.

facts.text: On appeal, Division Bench of Calcutta High Court consisting of Mookerjee A.C.J. and H.K. Bose J. accepted first respondent's contention and issued writ.

anchor.surface_text: But on appeal, a division bench of that High Court, companysisting of Mookerjee, A. C, J., and H.-K. Bose J., accepted the companytention of the first respondent and issued a writ as prayed for.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal directed against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is directed against the said order.

facts.text: It is not disputed that Universal Electric Motors operated in factory and interference attributable to local induction from factory.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that in the said factory a number of Universal Electric Motors are operated for the purpose of working electric drills and it is also established that the interference with the reception of messages at the Telegraph Wireless Station is, attributable to local induction from the said factory.

facts.text: Dispute centers on whether interference injuriously affects telegraph line within s.34 of Act.

anchor.surface_text: But the, dispute between the parties centers round the question whether the said interference with the reception of messages at the said Station injuriously affects any telegraph line within the meaning of s. 34 of the Act.

facts.text: Senior Electric Inspector filed affidavit stating operation of drills caused interference by induction to existing lines and receiving apparatus containing wires used for telegraphic communication.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case , the Senior Electric Inspector filed an affidavit wherein he stated it was established to my satisfaction that the operation and use of the Universal drills during the working hours of the factory caused serious interference by induction to the existing lines as well as to the receiving apparatus companytaining wires which are were expressly used for telegraphic companymunication at the said centre.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that telegraph line definition includes wires used in wireless receiving apparatus.

anchor.surface_text: If so, it follows Chit the receiving appartus employs telegraph lines within the meaning of s. 3 4  of the Telegraph Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order and dismissed petition filed by first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we set aside the order of the High Court and dismiss the petition filed by the first respondent.

facts.text: Telegraph Act passed in 1885.

anchor.surface_text: The Telegraph Act was passed in 1885.

facts.text: In 1914, s.3(1) of Telegraph Act amended to include receiving communications by electricity.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1914,s. 3 1  of the said Act was amended and the following words were inserted after the words apparatus for making transmitting or receiving. With the result that, after the amendment, receiving of companymunications by means of electricity was included in the definition.

arguments.claim: The word 'line' in 'telegraph line' connotes a defined channel of communication with physical existence; wireless telegraphy uses transmission through space, not a defined physical channel

anchor.surface_text: The first reason is that the word line in the expression telegraph line connotes the existence of a defined channel of communication which has got a physical existence and that wireless telegraphy is dependent upon transmission through space of electric waves and that is not a defined physical channel.

arguments.claim: Expression 'telegraph line' in s.34(2)(b) of Electricity Act, 1910 must be given the sense intended by Legislature in 1885 when Telegraph Act passed, as no new definition; could not have contemplated wireless

anchor.surface_text: The second reason given by the learned Judges is that the expression telegraph line, as used in s. 34 2  b  of the Indian Electricity Act, has, in the absence of any new definition in that Act., to be given the same sense as the Legislature had intended in 1885 by the definition of that expression in the earlier Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to consider the scope of the said maxim in its application to the interpretation of modern statutes. ... The maxim contemporanea expositio as laid down by Coke was applied to construing ancient statutes but not to interpreting Acts which are comparatively modern.

arguments.claim: Modern statutes should be interpreted broadly to include future developments and enlarged meanings attributable with time, as Legislature presumed aware in progressive society

Precedents support broad interpretation of 'telegraph' to include telephones, radio broadcasting despite post-enactment inventions: Edison Telephone, Radio Communication Canada, Brislan, James v Australia, Gannon Dunkerley

anchor.surface_text: Decided cases accepted the said liberal approach in construing modern statutes. In The Attorney-General v. The Edison Telephone Company of London ... the meaning of the words changes, but the changing circumstances illustrate and illuminate the full import of that meaning.

holdings.text: A wireless receiving station certainly receives communications by means of electricity, and therefore it is telegraph within the meaning of said definition.

holdings.text: a telegraph line is not defined to mean a defined continuous physical channel from the point of transmission to the point of reception. The definition... is comprehensive enough to take in any wire used for the purpose of an apparatus for receiving communications by means of electricity.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot accept this reasoning, for a telegraph line is number defined to mean a defined companytinuous physical channel from the point of transmission to the point of reception. The definition, as we have pointed out, is companyprehensive enough to take in any wire used for the purpose of an apparatus for receiving companymunications by means of electricity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.3(4) Telegraph Act does not require continuous channel; covers any wires used for receiving apparatus.

holdings.text: the maxim contemporanea expositio as laid down by Coke was applied to construing ancient statutes but not to interpreting Acts which are comparatively modern.

anchor.surface_text: The legal position may be summarized thus The maxim companytemporanea expositio as laid down by Coke was applied to companystruing ancient statutes but number to interpreting Acts which are companyparatively modern.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Authorities (Craies, Halsbury, Sutherland) limit maxim to ancient statutes; Electricity Act 1910 is modern.

holdings.text: unless a contrary intention appears, an interpretation should be given to the words used to take in new facts and situations, if the words are capable of comprehending them.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, unless a companytrary intention appears, an interpretation should be given to the words used to take in new facts and situations, if the words are capable of companyprehending them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Modern legislatures presumed aware of future developments in progressive society; supported by precedents (Edison Telephone, Radio Communication Canada, Brislan, James v Australia, Gannon Dunkerley).

holdings.text: the expression telegraph line is sufficiently comprehensive to take in the wires used for the purpose of the apparatus of the Post and Telegraph Wireless Station.

anchor.surface_text: we hold that the expression telegraph line is sufficiently companyprehensive to take in the wires used for the purpose of the apparatus of the Post and Telegraph Wireless Station.

precedents.citation: The Attorney-General v. The Edison Telephone Company of London 1

anchor.surface_text: In The Attorney-General v. The Edison Telephone Company of London 1 ,a telephone was held to be a telegraph within the meaning of the Telegraphs Acts, 1863 and 1869, although the telephone was number invented or companytemplated in 1869. Stephen, T., observed at p. 254 Of companyrse numberone supposes that the legislature intended to refer specifically to telephones many years before they were invented, but it is highly probable that they would, and it seems to us clear that they actually did, use language embracing future discoveries as to the use of electricity for the purpose of companyveying intelligence.

precedents.cited_proposition: telephone is a telegraph within the meaning of the Telegraphs Acts 1863 and 1869 though not invented then
precedents.cited_holding: legislature used language embracing future discoveries as to the use of electricity for conveying intelligence

precedents.citation: re Regulation and Control of-Radio Communication in Canada 2

anchor.surface_text: The Privy-Council in re Regulation and Control of-Radio Communication in Canada 2 held that broadcasting fell within the m eaning of the expression in s.92 of British North America Act,1867, though at the time when that Act was made broadcasting was number in vogue.

precedents.case_name: Regulation and Control of Radio Communication in Canada, In re
precedents.cited_proposition: broadcasting falls within expression in s.92 British North America Act 1867 though not in vogue then

precedents.citation: The King V. Brislan ex parte Williams 3

anchor.surface_text: In The King V. Brislan ex parte Williams 3 the question was whether a law of the Commonwealth Parliament with respect to radio broadcasting was one with respect to Postal, telegraphic telephonic and other like services under s. 1 5  of the Australian Commonwealth Act, and the Court held that the words were wide enough to take in radio broadcasting.

precedents.case_name: King v Brislan ex parte Williams
precedents.cited_proposition: radio broadcasting within postal, telegraphic, telephonic services

anchor.surface_text: In James v. Commonwealth of Australia 4 ,Lord Wright has state the principle in felicitous language thus the meaning of the words changes, but the changing circumstances illustrate and illuminate the full import of that meaning.

precedents.citation: The State of Madras V. Gannon Dunkerley and Co., Madras Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in companystruing the words sale of goods in Entry 48, List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Government of India Act, 1935, accepted the aforesaid principle in The State of Madras V. Gannon Dunkerley and Co., Madras Ltd. 1 ,and restated it at p. 416 thus The principle of these decisions. is that when, after the enactment of a legislation, new facts and situations arise which companyld number have been in its companytemplation, the statutory provisions companyld properly be applied to them if the words thereof are in a broad sense capable- of companytaining them.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v Gannon Dunkerley and Co (Madras) Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: statutory provisions can apply to new facts if words capable of containing them
